caseTitle: THE REPUBLIC v THE HIGH COURT, ACCRA(COMMERCIAL DIVISION)
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana ruled that Justice Tanko Amadu of the Commercial Division of the High Court lacked jurisdiction to hear and determine a contempt application after the 2008 legal vacation had ended, as his authority as a vacation judge had lapsed and there was no formal transfer of the case to his division. The applicant, Dr. Kwabena Appenteng, had been found guilty of contempt by Tanko Amadu J for allegedly violating a court order during the execution of a writ of possession, but challenged the ruling on grounds of lack of jurisdiction. The Supreme Court emphasized that while contempt is a substantive matter, the judge's authority was confined to the vacation period and did not extend beyond it. The Court also reaffirmed that certiorari is a discretionary remedy and will not be granted automatically, even for want of jurisdiction, if the party failed to raise a timely objection. The decision underscores the importance of respecting judicial divisions and procedural rules to prevent forum shopping and maintain judicial integrity.
verdict: The Supreme Court granted the application for certiorari, quashing the contempt ruling by Tanko Amadu J due to lack of jurisdiction.

rationaleHighlights: A judge of the Commercial Division lacked jurisdiction to hear a contempt case filed in another division after the legal vacation ended.
Jurisdiction during vacation is limited to the period and authority granted by the Chief Justice.
Certiorari is discretionary and not automatic, even for want of jurisdiction, if no objection was raised below.
Judicial divisions are administrative but must be respected to prevent forum shopping and chaos.
Statutory interpretation must reflect real-world application, not just linguistic analysis.
Transfer of cases between divisions requires formal authority, typically from the Chief Justice.
Judges cannot assume jurisdiction beyond their assigned or temporarily authorized scope.
Proper judicial administration requires adherence to procedural and territorial jurisdictional rules.
